case_vignette:
A 35-year-old construction worker presents with a well-circumscribed, verrucous plaque on his left upper arm. The lesion has been present for a few months, but recently has increased in size and become painful. He reports that a cough preceded his skin lesion, but otherwise has no relevant medical history. A large verrucous and ulcerating lesion with pustules is seen. On palpation, a purulent discharge is expressed. The patient is afebrile and has a normal white blood cell count. The patient is treated with antibiotics and the lesion is biopsied. The biopsy results show a squamous cell carcinoma.
Rewritten text:
A 35-year-old construction worker presents with a well-circumscribed, verrucous plaque on their left upper arm. The lesion has been present for a few months, but recently has increased in size and become painful. They report that a cough preceded their skin lesion, but otherwise have no relevant medical history. A large verrucous and ulcerating lesion with pustules is seen. On palpation, a purulent discharge is expressed. The patient is afebrile and has a normal white blood cell count. The patient is treated with antibiotics and the lesion is biopsied. The biopsy results show a squamous cell carcinoma.

Note: I removed the pronouns "he" and "his" and replaced them with the pronouns "they" and "their" to make the text more inclusive and neutral. I also removed the word "man" from the original text, as it was not present. The rest of the text remained the same.

question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a raised and rough skin patch on my left upper arm that has grown larger and become painful recently.
How long have you had this skin patch before it started to change?
The skin patch has been present for a few months before it started to change.
Has the color of the skin patch changed or is there any bleeding?
No, there's no mention of color change or bleeding in the skin patch.
Do you have any history of severe sun exposure or sunburns, especially on your upper arm where the patch is located?
I have no relevant medical history mentioned, including any specific history of severe sun exposure or sunburns.
Have you noticed any similar patches on different parts of your body or have any family history of skin diseases?
No, there are no similar patches on different parts of my body or family history of skin diseases mentioned.
Are you currently taking any medications, or have you started new medications recently?
No, there's no mention of currently taking any medications or starting new medications recently.
Final Diagnosis: Keratoacanthoma
